body:
See #797 - at that point we moved out of spec. But the spec used to add the `<` character as an attribute name, not to the tag name. https://html.spec.whatwg.org/multipage/parsing.html#tag-name-state

Will review moving closer to spec and impact.
OK, I've aligned it to the current spec. That allows tag names like `a hello OneHello`). That's pretty gross IMO, but better for us to be consistent.

issue.title: Tokeniser: Tag attributes that follow '<' character in attribute name are lost

repository.name: jsoup
repository.description: jsoup: the Java HTML parser, built for HTML editing, cleaning, scraping, and XSS safety.

issue.body:
The Tokeniser logic for parsing attribute names considers a '<' character to be the end of the tag. This is not consistent with the way the browsers engines that I tested on MacOS (Brave/Chrome, Safari, Firefox) handle this case.

As demonstrated here: http://try.jsoup.org/~X8uusGL-o4nn_aiT4XVefMuXW0Q

Consider the tag`<a before="foo" <junk after="page.html">`.

In this case, jsoup will associate the `before` attribute with the `a` tag. It will then process `<junk` as a new tag and associate the `after` attribute with it.

Handling more consistently with browsers might assign the unvalued attribute `"<junk"` to the `a` tag and continue processing additional attributes.

body:
This change just pointed me to some invalid HTML that I was generating, so thanks! :slightly_smiling_face: I was generating (more or less) the following: ```html
``` 1.18.1 turned that into ```html
``` Now, with 1.18.2, it get ```html
``` I assume that it's related to this change. I just wanted to make sure that the new behavior is expected.

Thanks @jochenberger -- yes that is what we would expect now. The previous #797 behavior was probably a better experience for this case, but ultimately lead to too much difference betwen browsers/spec and jsoup.

The `th<` tag is getting promoted ahead of the `table` tag in your instance due to the `table` parsing rules that move non-table elements out of the table.

issue.title: parsing an erroneous HTML tag

repository.name: jsoup
repository.description: jsoup: the Java HTML parser, built for HTML editing, cleaning, scraping, and XSS safety.

issue.body: Good day to all. In jsoup v. 1.18.2 and 1.18.3, there was a problem with parsing an erroneous HTML tag, for example:
